flows.name: R - Emotional Regulation

actions.text: It's not always easy to understand our emotions, or to accept or express how we feel. That is why we created this chatbot to talk with you about Emotions✔️!
Want to learn more? Reply Yes or No.
I did not understand that, please respond with YES or NO

D. Managing difficult feelings that are persistent or strong 👧👦🏽
Leaving so soon? We look forward to hearing from you in the future. 👋 If you change your mind you can always come back by replying with the word 'EMOTIONS'.

flows.name: M - Emotional Regulation - Understanding emotions

actions.text: Everybody has emotions, and our emotions are important because they tell us something. For example:
• Fear might tell us something is unsafe, and that we should be careful and look for safety.
• Frustration might tell us something isn't going the way we hoped and that we need to solve a problem or ask for help

• Sadness might mean that we are responding to something that happened, like a loss, a fight, or even a song or a movie. These are all different and some are more intense than others, but they all matter.
• Joy might tell us something is good for our well-being and that we should do it more often or regularly
But knowing how we feel isn't always easy. Or sometimes we know how we feel, but we can't really put it into words.
Reply NEXT if you want to see a list of emotions that can help give you some words to identify how you're feeling.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT

How are you feeling right now:

• Glad?
• Hopeful?
• Cheerful? Excited? 
• Sad?
• Angry?
• Frustrated?
• Confused?
• Annoyed?
All of these are emotions that we as people are capable of experiencing from time to time.
Reply NEXT to practice knowing what you're feeling.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT
This exercise is called a body scan:
•  Sitting comfortably, start by taking 2-3 deep breath in through the nose, and out through the mouth.
• As you take your third breath out, close your eyes. Notice how the body feels right now. You might feel a sense of stillness or restlessness, heaviness or lightness, relaxed or tense.
• Starting at the top of the head, slowly scan down through the body, noticing what feels comfortable and what feels uncomfortable.

. 
Remember, you're not trying to change anything, just noticing how the body feels as you scan down slowly and notice each and every part of the body, all the way down to the toes.

Now, take 2 more deep breaths as we come to the end of this exercise. Breathe in and out, breathe in and out. When you are ready, open your eyes and return your attention to the present moment. How did you feel? What were the emotions that you identified? Sometimes, this exercise can be difficult, but it might be one way to identify how you're feeling.
Reply NEXT to learn some other ways to identify feelings.
I did not understand that, please respond with any options

• Take time to connect with a friend and tell them about how your day or week is going. Think about how you're feeling and what's been on your mind. If you feel comfortable, you can talk about what's been challenging or difficult.
• Start writing down whatever thoughts come to your mind or try one of these journal prompts. What feelings have you experienced, and what was exciting or energizing? What was challenging?
• Go on a walk outside or sit for a moment and try to notice what you feel, what it says about your mood, what's going through your mind if anything at all.
• Find a song that relates to the mood you are feeling

What would you like to learn about next?

A. Accepting how you feel
B. Expressing how you feel
C. Managing difficult feelings that are persistent or strong
D. End the conversation
I did not understand that, please respond with any options

arguments: C  Managing difficult feelings that are persistent or strong

flows.name: M - Emotional Regulation - Accepting how you feel

actions.text:
In your context, are there some feelings that are considered unacceptable?

1. Yes
2. No
3. Not sure
I did not understand that, please respond with any options

All our feelings matter and are natural. But some of us have been taught to reject certain emotions because they are considered unacceptable, bad, or embarrassing in our cultures and families. Have you ever come across any of these beliefs?
• "It's ok for girls to be sad and cry but not boys"
• "Being afraid shows you are a weak"
• "It's not ok to be angry at your parents."
• "If you are successful, you will be happy."
• "People who are frustrated just aren't trying hard enough"
📢 These are common misbeliefs about emotions, and often they cause us to reject how we feel. Reply NEXT to learn about accepting how we feel
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT

Do you agree or disagree? Our beliefs and values influence the way we think about emotions and how we do or don't take care of our emotional well-being. The reality is that no matter what we think about certain feelings and whether we want them or not,  we all experience both highs and lows in life
Accepting our emotions means:

1. Acknowledging our feelings, no matter what they may be. You could say to yourself:
"I am going through a difficult moment right now. I feel _______"

2. Allowing ourselves to feel the way we do. You could say to yourself:
"Difficult feelings are part of being human. I feel this way because _______________."

3. To not judge ourselves for how we feel. You could say to yourself:
"It is ok for me to feel this way and I am/can____________."
📢 Reply NEXT to practice accepting emotions.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT
1. Think about someone you know, your friend, your neighbour or someone else close to you.
2. Now, think about what you would say to them if they felt sad, angry or anxious. Try to think of some of the kind or comforting things that you might say to them.
3. Next time you feel yourself judging your emotions harshly, remember what you would say to your friend and try to say it to yourself.
4. And remember to be kind to yourself, no matter what you are feeling!

What else would you like to explore?

A. Understanding emotions
B. Expressing how you feel
C. Managing difficult feelings that are persistent or strong
D. End the conversation
I did not understand that, please respond with any options

arguments: C Managing difficult feelings that are persistent or strong

flows.name: M - Emotional Regulation - Expressing how you feel

actions.text: It is important to be able to express our emotions. What happens if we don't?

• The feelings can overwhelm you by getting stronger and more intense over time
• Lead you to feel alone or stressed
• Negatively impact your relationships and your health (physical and mental
Choosing how we express our emotions is just as important as expressing our emotions. There are many ways to express our emotions that can be helpful. For example:

• Cry,laugh, or talk with a friend
• Draw, paint, write , play music, or any form of art
• Do something physical like run, move your body around, go for a walk, dance
Are there other ways that you express emotions?
Reply NEXT to hear more about expressing emotions
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT
Sometimes we might express our emotions in ways that can be harmful to ourselves or others. For example:
• When someone is angry, they might become violent
• When someone is frustrated, they might shout or say unkind words to others
• When someone is sad, they might isolate themselves from others

• When someone feels a lot of pain that is difficult to express in other ways, they might end up harming themselves physically, which might feel like the only solution at the time but it can be very dangerous. This is called self-harm, and it can be difficult to manage, but remember that you don't have to do it on your own.
If you need to speak with a trained professional now, reply HELP <Country to identify helpline-should be available 24 hours a day>
📢 Otherwise, reply NEXT to practice choosing methods of emotional expression.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT
Choosing a mode of emotional expression is an important part of taking care of how we feel. Let's practice!
• Sometimes people use singing to express how they feel. Can you think of a way to sing how you feel?
Sometimes people use dancing to express how they feel. Can you dance the way you feel?
Sometimes people use writing to express how they feel. Can you write out how you are feeling?
These are all modes of emotional expression. Try them and see what works for you!

What else would you like to explore?

A. Understanding emotions
B. Accepting how you feel
C. Managing difficult feelings that are persistent or strong
D. End the conversation
I did not understand that, please respond with any option

arguments: C Managing difficult feelings that are persistent or strong

flows.name: M - Emotional Regulation - Managing difficult feelings

actions.text: It's natural to face difficult emotions from time to time. Most of us worry sometimes - about things like friendships or the future - and feel anxious when we're under stress, like at exam time. But afterwards, we usually calm down and feel better. And if we are struggling, we can find ways to care for ourselves and manage some difficult feelings through focusing on coping mechanisms that might be helpful. To learn more about stress and coping mechanisms, type <STRESS> <Link to Stress Management>

This does not mean that all situations are easy to manage through self-care. Some emotions might be extremely difficult, and some might even be life-threatening. If you are in a crisis situation and you need to talk to someone immediately, reply HELP <country to identify appropriate helpline-should be available 24 hours>
Even if you don't want to talk to anyone, there is some information, I can share with you. Would you like more information. Reply 'YES' or 'NO'
I did not understand that, please respond with YES or NO

I want to warn you that some information on this page may be difficult to read or may cause strong or upsetting feelings. Please only carry on reading if you feel safe to do so. If at any time, you do not feel comfortable, please do not continue. And if you are feeling distressed, reply HELP to speak to someone. <Country to identify helpline-should be available 24 hours a day>

Thank you for participating! 🥳 Remember, I'm always here if you need information!

If you would like to have some information or want to talk to someone about your feelings and emotions, you can contact: 
 
-Countries must include relevant referral mechanisms-

flow.name: R - Thanks for participating!

actions.text: 📢 Reply NEXT to continue.

It is a normal part of life to feel down and sad sometimes.  But if those feelings have become very deep and intense, and you don't know what to do about them, there might be some ways that you choose to cope that are harmful to you. For example:

• When someone feels a lot of pain that is difficult to express in other ways, they might end up harming themselves physically, which might feel like the only solution at the time but it can be very dangerous. This is called self-harm, and it can be difficult to manage, but remember that you don't have to do it on your own
• You might think the only solution is to end your life. But there are ways and people to support you, and you can get through this. Your life is worth living, and you deserve support.
If you need to speak with a trained professional now, reply HELP <Country to identify helpline-should be available 24 hours a day>
📢 Otherwise, reply NEXT to think about some other ways to manage difficult emotions.
I did not understand that, please respond with HELP or NEXT
Managing difficult feelings can be hard. Here are some ways that you could consider:

• Sometimes it can take time to find new ways to cope, and that's normal. In the meantime, think about other things you can do in the moment. Can you find ways to keep yourself safe / distracted - It's really important to keep yourself as safe as possible to manage your difficult emotions and reduce your risk of serious self-injury? These might include methods such as hitting a cushion or pillow or tearing up a magazine or newspaper, reaching out to a friend so they can spend some time with you, going for a run or listening to music that you find soothing. Try something that works for you!

• Try talking to someone you trust. If you've been struggling with difficult feelings, self-harming or thinking about ending your life, it's a good idea to talk to someone you trust, like a family member, friend, or teacher. Remember, asking for help is a sign of strength, and if you need it, help is available. If you need to speak with a trained professional now, reply HELP <Country to identify helpline-should be available 24 hours a day>

What else would you like to explore?

A. Understanding emotions
B. Accepting how you feel
C. Expressing how you feel
D. End the conversation

flows.name: M - Relationship Skills - Dealing with challenges in relations

actions.text: We all experience many kinds of relationships in our lives 💜🤍💛,  for example with our friends, our family and siblings, or our teachers, to name a few. Relationships are all around us and are important for making us feel supported, cared for, and understood 🤗. Do you agree?
I did not understand that, please respond with any of the options

arguments: IM I'M NOT nop no SURE

actions.text: However, there are also differences between people or difficult situations and stresses that can sometimes lead to disagreements 😓 or a sense of unbalance in the relationship.  When was the last time you had a disagreement with someone?

Choose:  

A. Today
B. Yesterday
C. Last week
D. A while ago
E. I can't remember
I did not understand that, please respond with any of the options

flow.name: C - Inactivity

actions.text: Many people experience disagreements or unhappiness in their relationships. But remember ⚠️⚠️, disagreement and difference are not the same thing as being bullied or harmed.

If you are ever feeling unsafe or hurt in a relationship, try reaching out to a trusted friend or adult for support 🤚. Asking for help isn't always easy but it is a sign of courage and a way to take care of yourself.
We can't always control the way others behave, but we can develop skills that will help us better manage our relationships. The way we communicate and act are two of these skills!
What are 3 main communication styles?
Assertive: clearly saying what we feel and want in an honest, respectful way.
Passive: not saying or being unclear about what we feel and want.
Aggressive: saying what we feel and demanding what we want in an unkind or disrespectful way
These different communciation styles can be observed through the words we use, our tone of voice, our facial expressions, and our body language.
Someone assertive might say what they feel and want in a respectful way, use eye contact 👁️, and give the other person a chance to say what they feel and want without interrupting them.
Someone passive might not saying anything, keep looking down, let the other person get their way, and allow others be disrespectful or hurt them.
Someone aggressive might say unkind words, physically hurt others, interrupt frequently, yell or raise their voice, criticize, blame and even threaten others.

Assertive communication is useful because it respectfully lets the other person know what you think, feel, and need while also giving them a chance to do the same. This allows for us to strengthen our connection with the other person 👐. Communicating assertively is a skill that may not come naturally but can be learned and practiced.

Assertive communication can make a big difference, but even then, some relationships can be tricky. 
When you've tried communicating with the other person and it isn't working out, you might consider:
Asking for help from an objective person that you trust, such as a mutual friend or teacher 👩‍🏫.

Give some space in a relationship or even considering ending the relationship, because there is no way to overcome the differences. This is easier to do in some relationships than in others. For example, with family members, often we would need to find an alternative solution because simply ending the relationship is not possible, so seeking help may be more realistic.

Apologising for your role in any disagreement and forgiving your friend so that you can move on because the friendship has been such an important one in the past. But if there are some feelings that are still left unaddressed, there is a possibility of problems arising again in the future.
Being able to identify and access support in managing difficult relationships is important. Who is one person you could turn to for help?

A.  Friend
B. Parent, sibling, or other family member
C. Teacher
D. Coach
E. Co-worker
F. Other
G. I can't think of anyone
You can select more than one option by separating each letter with a space (Example: A C D)
I did not understand that, please respond with any of the options

arguments: A B C D E F G

actions.text: If you can't think of anyone, take a moment to search for a local helpline or support service. Chatlines for people facing difficult situations have helped many young people, and they may be of use to you too And if you need someone to talk to, reply HELP to speak to someone. <Country to identify helpline-should be available 24 hours a day>

What else would you like to explore?

flows.name: M - Relationship Skills - Being a good friend

actions.text:
The good things you look for in a friend are also things you can try to be better at as a friend 🤗.

What do you think are things that help build healthy connections?

Here are some ideas:
✅Listening 👂🏼 and talking to one another.
✅ Asking someone to help if you are unable to talk to one another calmly.
✅Taking responsibility for your own actions, and apologizing when you have done something wrong.
✅ Being honest with the person about what you need and want.
✅ Showing you respect and accept someone for who they are.
✅ Showing gratitude and expressing appreciation for others.
These are all things that can help strengthen 💪 our connections with others. What do you think might weaken our connections with others?

Some things might include:
⛔ Ignoring or avoiding each other 
⛔ Doing something that physically hurts others 
⛔ Blaming one another 
⛔ Focusing 🤔 on who is right and who is wrong 
⛔ Name calling

These things might not be so helpful.

Reply NEXT to see some tips on how to be an active listener.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT
Listening is important for understanding and connecting with others. What might you say or how might you act to show you are actively listening to someone?

Think about the following:
- Don't interrupt 
- Put any distractions aside  
- Summarize what you've heard them say

For example, "It sounds like you were worried about what he thinks of you. Is that right?"

-Ask follow-up questions about what the person is saying 
-Nod your head and looking at the person while they're speaking
Yup, those are all great ways to show that you are paying attention to what the other person is saying.

Have you heard of a skill called empathy? Empathy means understanding what another person might be feeling and is an important part of our connections to others. This is something we can all practice and get better at.

Let's use an example that a lot of people can relate to. Imagine a friend is struggling with a homework assignment and expresses anxiety about it. These are some ways that you can demonstrate empathy.
1. Reflect back what someone has said to you. For example, you could say 'What I'm hearing is that this homework assignment is especially difficult for you, and it's causing a lot of anxiety'

2. Express that you might know how someone else is feeling and identify with that feeling. For example, you could say 'When I have a hard time with homework I feel stressed out, too. Biology is the worst for me'

3. Show someone that you care about them when they are going through a difficult time. For example, you could say 'I'm sorry you're stressed out about the homework. Is there something I can help with?

Empathy often leads to action or behavior that is helpful to others. For example, think of the way some people use their time to volunteer in their communities, or think of times when you yourself may have done something kind for someone. The root of kindness is empathy, and it can make a huge difference in people's lives.
Now, try putting these skill to practice by checking-in with a friend and asking them how they are doing!

What else would you like to explore?

A. Dealing with difficult relationships
B. Main Menu
C. Ending the conversation

flows.name: M - Relationship Skills - Being kind to myself

actions.text:
Do you show yourself the same kindness you would to your friends? 

A. Yes
B. No
C. I'm not sure
I did not understand that, please respond with any of the options
The way we talk to ourselves is also very important. Sometimes our inner voice 💭 can be kind and supportive and other times it can be harsh or judgemental.

How we talk to ourselves can be affected by what other people say to us 👈🏻 or what we see in the world and compare ourselves to. This might be about the way we look, what possessions we have or don't have, or what we do or don't do.
We all judge ourselves without even knowing it and it can have a real impact on how we feel and behave.
What are 3 criticisms you might have about yourself?

If you can't think of any, try filling in these blanks:

"I'm so bad at _______."
"My worst body feature is  __________."
"I'll never be able to _________."
Now, imagine someone said these things about your friend. How would you respond in their defence? 🤔

If you can't think of any, try filling in these blanks:

"But they are so good at  _____"
"Their best features are _______."
"Remember the time that you were able to ______."

When we've got an inner voice saying judgemental things to us, it can be hard to feel good about ourselves. So next time you catch your inner voice being harsh, remember to stand up for yourself in the same way you would for your friend 💪🏽.
Challenging your inner voice 🛑 might seem unusual or awkward at first. But the more we practice it, the more normal it becomes.
Start treating yourself with kindness.
While we often admire the strengths in others, sometimes we overlook the strengths we have in ourselves 💪🏽.
Think of 3 things that you consider to be personal strengths. Remember, everyone is good at something, and everyone adds value to the world 🌏
If you have a hard time coming up with personal strengths, here are a few examples to get you started. Maybe you really enjoy writing or painting 🎨, so one of their strengths would be creativity.
Maybe you are quick to try out new things, so one of their strengths would be that they're adventurous ✨✨.
You can make a list on your phone ✍🏾 of your personal strengths, and keep adding more from time to time. The more you do so, the more conscious 💡 and aware of your own strengths you will be.
Take your time to practice these tips and remember:

What else would you like to explore?

A. Dealing with difficult relationships
B. Main Menu
C. Ending the conversation

flow.name: M - Mental Health Literacy - What is mental health?
M - Mental Health Literacy - Asking for support
M - Mental Health Literacy - Myths and facts about mental health

flows.name: M - Mental Health Literacy - What is mental health?

actions.text: So what exactly is ✨ mental health ✨?

Well, mental health is a part of everyone's life. Sometimes we can feel very good, and other times we can feel distressed. Think of mental health as a spectrum, which we are all on, and our place on this spectrum can change from time to time. 🧠
📢 Reply NEXT to learn more about mental health conditions.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT
There are a range of mental health conditions that can be diagnosed and supported by psychologists, psychiatrists, and other trained healthcare professionals. 👩‍⚕️🧑‍⚕
Sometimes our cultures and the media don't always understand what it means to be a person living with a mental health condition. 🤔

Many people with mental health conditions do well in school, work, have good relationships, and live their lives as best as they can. While it can sometimes be hard to go about their daily routine, with the right support, they very often can feel better over time. 😁
Remember, while we all experience mental health in unique ways, we are still a part of the same community, so our mental health and our experiences are connected. We're in this together!🫂

You don't need to have a diagnosed mental health condition to experience emotional distress. While balancing school, work, relationships, and regular life challenges have you ever felt stressed, sad, lonely, afraid, or anxious? 😔
📢 Reply YES to read more.
I did not understand that, please respond with YES

It is 🌟 normal 🌟 to feel difficult emotions from time to time. Here are some things to keep in mind:

• All of these experiences are a part of life and our feelings are natural reactions to these experiences. 🍃
• When a challenging situation starts to improve, we usually start to feel better as well. 🌱
Have you ever had a disagreement with a friend before? It might have made you feel anxious or sad, but once you talked and figured out a path forward, did you start to feel better? 💬

🏅When we're going through a difficult time, we can all benefit from getting some help. And it's especially important to ask for help from a trusted adult if our difficult feelings feel like too much, last a long time, or make it hard to do our daily routine.

What would you like to learn about next?

A. Asking for support or being asked for support 🤗 💪
B. Myths and facts about mental health ❌✅
C. End the conversation
I did not understand that, please respond with any options

arguments: A Asking for support or being asked for support
B Myths and facts about mental health

flow.name: M - Mental Health Literacy - Asking for support

actions.text:

flow.name: M - Main menu
R - Thanks for participating!

flows.name: M - Mental Health Literacy - Asking for support

actions.text: It can feel scary to admit that you need support, but it is a sign of courage and strength. 🏆🏅

People might need support for various reasons. They might be feeling low, they might need someone to talk to, or they might be struggling and in a difficult or even a crisis situation. There is no 'right' and 'wrong' reason to seek support. It's your decision!
📢 Reply NEXT to learn about how to get support
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT
It's helpful to ask for support when you need:

• Comfort or encouragement, try talking to a friend or family member who you trust 🫂
• Advice, ask an adult you trust like a parent, family member, older friend, or teacher 👩‍🏫👨‍🏫

• Help, if you can, talk to someone in your community like a counselor, health care worker, or community leader. If this is challenging, try talking first to someone you trust, like maybe a teacher or family member, who can help you reach out for help.📲 You may even find an available helpline that you can call or reach online. <insert local resource>
• New ideas, interact with other young people who might be going through similar situations🧍‍♀️🧍‍♂️
📢 Reply NEXT to read more about how to ask for help
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT
Asking for help can feel scary or hard, but getting help from other people can change your life.😊 If you are struggling and don't know what to say or how to ask for help, try these:

• When you don't know what you need: "I'm feeling ___________. I'm not sure what to ask for, but I think I need some support. Are you free to talk (day/time)?" 🫂

• When you feel stuck: "I'm struggling. Can we (meet up/talk)? I'd love your help in thinking about some ideas and making a plan." 💯

• When you don't want to talk about it: "I'm in a bad place but I'm also not ready to talk about it. I'd love to chat/do an activity together to distract me." 🧘‍♂️🧘‍♀️
When you need to feel connected: "Can you call or message me (on date/every day) to make sure I'm doing OK?"💻📲
📢 Reply NEXT for tips on what to do if someone is asking you for support.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT

We all have a role to play in our own mental health and in the mental health of our friends. While you might ask a friend for support, it's important to understand and practice how you would respond to a friend asking YOU for support. Remember, wanting a good friend means that you need to be a good friend too. Try these tips to see how you can be supportive for a friend in need.

Finding the words to start talking to your friend about how they're feeling can be difficult. But really, there's no wrong way to begin and however you do it, they'll probably just appreciate you're trying. Here are some examples of conversation starters to get an idea:

• Your first response: when you receive a call or message from a friend asking for support, you can respond by letting them know that you are here to support them and schedule a time to talk to them or meet in person. Try this sample message:

                                                                                  Thank you for sharing this with me. I know this isn't easy.

• Emphasize trust: these types of conversations usually involve sensitive topics. Make sure that, if your friend is not at risk of harming themselves or others, the information that was shared with you should stay confidential. 🤫
• Be present: focus on your friend and listen attentively to their inputs, put away any distractions. Be sure to do the same when responding 🤜🤛

• Comfort them: there isn't a wrong thing to say. But you could try 'you won't always feel like this' or 'you're not alone in this - there's lot of people who care about you' .Ask them what would help - it could just be being there for them, or they might want help talking to an adult or looking for support options
• Do the things you both enjoy together - sometimes just doing the normal things you do together like watching a film or going for a walk can make a big difference to how they're feeling.
• Keep in contact - ask them how they're doing, keep inviting them to join in, and keep sending the occasional message just to check in, even if they don't reply.
• Do something nice - like just sending a message to make them smile or laugh, or planning something small for them to look forward to, like a sleepover or a trip to the cinema.
• Be patient - your friendship might feel different for a while, but there will still be good times and they will be glad if you can stick by them.

• Support them in reaching out for help: if your friend has been experiencing difficult feelings and needs help, encourage them and support them in finding and speaking with an adult who can help, such as a parent, teacher, a counselor, or a health care professional. 👨‍⚕️👩‍⚕️You could even offer to go with them to talk to them.

What else would you like to explore?

A. What is mental health?
B. Myths and facts about mental health ❌✅
C. End the conversation
I did not understand that, please respond with any options

arguments: B Myths and facts about mental health

flows.name: M - Mental Health Literacy - Myths and facts about mental health

actions.text: Understanding myths about mental health can help our communities break the stigma and create ways for starting conversations and getting help. Here are some common myths that people sometimes here about mental health, and it's helpful to know what the facts are, so here are some facts too.

❌Myth: If a person has a mental health condition, it means the person is not smart. 🤨

✅Fact: Mental health conditions can affect anyone. It does not matter how smart they are if they have a lot of friends, or how much money they make. 🤯

❌Myth: You only need to take care of your mental health if you have a mental health condition.🤦‍♂️🤦‍♀️

✅Fact: Everyone has mental health and should take active steps to work on their well-being and improve their mental health.
😁🧠 Everyone should also take active steps to create habits that help them lead healthy and safe lifestyles.
📢 Reply NEXT to find out more.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT

❌Myth: Teenagers don't deal with poor mental health. They just have mood swings and rebel to get attention.😑

✅Fact: Teenagers often have mood swings, but that does not mean that they don't experience mental health challenges. 

➡️14% of the world's teens experience mental health conditions. 
➡️In the 10-15 age group, self-harm is the 5th leading cause of death. 
➡️Half of all mental health conditions start by the age of 14.
📢 Reply NEXT to find out more.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT

❌Myth: Nothing can be done to protect us from developing mental health conditions. 🤔 

✅Fact: Many things can protect us from developing mental health conditions, including learning how to manage our emotions and interact with people around us, getting help early on, creating supportive and warm relationships, having a positive school environment, and healthy sleep patterns.🏆
📢 Reply NEXT to find out more.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT

❌Myth: A mental health condition is a sign of weakness; if the person were stronger, they would not have this condition. 🙄

✅Fact: A mental health condition has nothing to do with being weak. It is not something people can choose to have or not have. In fact, realizing that you need help and asking for it requires great strength and courage. 🏋‍♀️🏋‍♂️ Anyone can develop a mental health condition.

❌Myth: Teenagers who get good grades and have a lot of friends will not have mental health conditions because they have nothing to be depressed or anxious about. 📒📈

✅Fact: Mental health conditions can affect anyone regardless of their socioeconomic status or how good their life seems at face value. 🧍‍♂️🧍‍♀️
Young people doing well in school may feel pressure to succeed, which can cause anxiety, or they may have other challenges at home.

What else would you like to explore?

A. What is mental health?
B. Asking for support or being asked for support🤗 💪
C. End the conversation
I did not understand that, please respond with any options

arguments: B Asking for support or being asked for support

flows.name: R - Stress Management

actions.text: Hi U-Reporters 👋! Have you ever thought about the difference between feeling stress and feeling too much stress 🤔?
Would you like to hear more about understanding and managing stress? Reply Yes or No.
Leaving so soon? We look forward to hearing from you in the future. 👋 If you change your mind you can always come back by replying with the word STRESS.
I did not understand that, please respond with YES or NO

Great 👏🏼! Stress is what we feel when we are worried, uncomfortable, or pressured by something. Stress is natural and can sometimes help us to perform better at work, school or in our daily lives. But when we experience too much stress or for too long, it can start to have an unhelpful effect on us. This is why it's important to manage our stress.

Which topic would you like to explore further?
A. Understanding my stress
B. Managing my stress
I did not understand that, please respond with A or B

flow.name: M - Stress Management - Understanding my stress
M - Stress Management - Managing My Stress

flows.name: R - Binary Answers
M - Stress Management - Understanding my stress

actions.text:
How often do you feel stressed? 

A. Never 
B. Occasionally
C. All the time
I did not understand that, please respond with any of the options

Most people experience stress from time to time.  And for adolescents, it's important to remember that your body and your brain are developing very quickly. There's a lot happening, and all these changes can also affect the way that stress impacts you.

We also know that life is full of challenges, so it's natural to become stressed about life sometimes. But when it becomes too much, stress can be a problem.

Reply NEXT to explore the ways that we can identify stress and the ways we can understand our own stress levels.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT

What are some of the ways that too much stress might impact you?

• What does it feel like in your body?
• How does it affect your thinking?
• How might you act differently?
• How might stress affect our emotions?

Stress can affect us physically- sometimes our bodies might feel very tense, our hearts can beat faster and it can become harder to sleep. 
Stress can also impact how we think. It can make us less able to concentrate, and even, less productive.

Stress can also make us act differently. When we experience strong feelings of stress, we might be more likely to respond with irritation or anger, or we might become very withdrawn or isolate ourselves, depending on how it makes us feel.
Some stress is natural, but too much stress can really have an impact on our emotions, causing us to feel sad, upset or worried. And this can impact how we relate to other people too.

Reply FRIENDS if you want to learn more about relationships <Link to FRIENDS chatbot> 

Reply NEXT if you want to think more about identifying stressors and understanding your levels of stress.
wait for the link of chatbot
I did not understand that, please respond with any of the options

Some things that we know cause stress for young people include:

1. School
2. Thinking about the future
3. Family
4. Friendships
5. Romantic relationships

What are some of the things that might be causing you stress in your life? Knowing this can be the first step in coping with stress.

One other thing that could be useful is to check how stressed you are feeling.  An easy way to do this from time to time is to have your own 'pressure scale'. Think of a scale that starts at 0, which means stress-free, and ends at 10, too much stress. If you had to give the stress you are feeling a number between 0 and 10, what would it be?

A lot of people feel some stress regularly, but if your pressure scale is very high all the time, it could be a sign that you should talk to someone you trust or reach out for help.

What else would you like to explore?

A. Managing stress
B. Main Menu
C. Ending the conversation

flows.name: M - Stress Management - Managing My Stress

actions.text:
How well do you feel like you are able to manage your stress?

A. Very well-I get stressed but I find it okay to deal with it
B. Somewhat-I get stressed and sometimes I manage it well but sometimes not so well
C. Not well at all-I am constantly stressed and struggle to manage it
I did not understand that, please respond with any options

That's great! Managing stress is a really important skill. Do you feel like you'd like to learn more? 

Reply YES or NO
Stress is part of all of our lives, so don't be too hard on yourself if you struggle with managing it sometimes.

There are many habits we can practice that might help us keep our stress at low levels. These include things like:

1. Getting enough sleep. This is different for each person, but usually at least 8 hours is ideal
2. Being active. This could be on your own like walking or dancing, or in a team sport, but at least 20 minutes a day of physical activity can be helpful
3. Make time for things that you enjoy, and this includes spending time with the people you care about and have fun with
4. Get enough time away from your screen- It's tempting to be on your phone or on your computer all day, but sometimes this can become too much, especially if it makes you feel disconnected from others. We know sometimes being on your phone or using social media can also make you feel connected, but having a balance is important.
Are there other habits that you can think of that might be helpful to manage day to day stress? Try keeping a list of these helpful habits. You can add to it at any time.
Being able to access and identify support
I did not understand that, please respond with YES or NO

Those habits can actually help you feel better and  prevent stress, but what about when you are already under pressure? Take a few moments to think about all the ways that you and people your age deal with stress. Think of as many or as little as you can. And then type NEXT
There are many different ways to cope with stress. And I'm sure you know many of these just from thinking about them.

Some ways of dealing with stress are helpful, and others can actually be harmful. For example, some people use exercise to help them calm strong feelings, while others might avoid the tasks that they need to do, which might be unhelpful. Some people talk to a friend when they feel upset, while others turn to substances, which can be harmful.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT

These are all ways of coping with stress, but they might have different results because some are more helpful than others. 
Reply NEXT to learn more about choosing helpful coping styles.
Let's list some of the ways that people deal with stress. You may have come up with some of these already:

1. Listening to music that helps you calm down
2. Being physically violent or aggressive
3. Watching a TV show that relaxes you
4. Smoking cigarettes
5. Going for a walk or a run
6. Talking to a friend
7. Drinking alcohol

These are all coping mechanisms, and they may reduce stress, but not all of them have the same benefits and the same risks. Being aggressive, smoking or drinking, for example, may momentarily make it seem you are less stressed, but they can be very harmful to you.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT
Reply NEXT to read more about choosing coping mechanisms.
I did not understand that, please respond with NEXT

Let's say you are in a stressful situation. Whatever it may be, try completing this sentence: When I feel stressed, I often manage it by...

Now think about the benefits and the risks of your choice. 

1. Are there more benefits than risks?
2. Are the risks worth it?
3. Are there alternative ways to cope with stress?

Now, try completing the sentence again: When I feel stressed, I could try managing it by...

It doesn't have to be one answer, and the answer may change too. But it's important to remember that you can try different ways to manage it. These are called coping strategies.

Being able to identify and access support in managing stress is important. Who is one person you could turn to for help?

A.  Friend
B. Parent, sibling, or other family member
C. Teacher
D. Coach
E. Co-worker
F. Other
G. I can't think of anyone
You can select more than one option by separating each letter with a space (Example: A C D)
I did not understand that, please respond with any of the options

arguments: A B C D E F G

actions.text: If you can't think of anyone, take a moment to search for a local helpline or support service. Chatlines for people facing difficult situations have helped many young people, and they may be of use to you too. And you can also find out more about reaching out for help by replying HELP <Countries to provide chatline number-should be available 24 hours a day>
